And the answer of Abraham's people was not but that they said, "Kill him or burn him," but Allah saved him from the fire. Indeed in that are signs for a people who believe.

And [Abraham] said, "You have only taken, other than Allah, idols as [a bond of] affection among you in worldly life. Then on the Day of Resurrection you will deny one another and curse one another, and your refuge will be the Fire, and you will not have any helpers."
And Lot believed him. [Abraham] said, "Indeed, I will emigrate to [the service of] my Lord. Indeed, He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise."
And We gave to Him Isaac and Jacob and placed in his descendants prophethood and scripture. And We gave him his reward in this world, and indeed, he is in the Hereafter among the righteous.
And [mention] Lot, when he said to his people, "Indeed, you commit such immorality as no one has preceded you with from among the worlds.

Indeed, you approach men and obstruct the road and commit in your meetings [every] evil." And the answer of his people was not but they said, "Bring us the punishment of Allah, if you should be of the truthful."
He said, "My Lord, support me against the corrupting people."
And when Our messengers came to Abraham with the good tidings, they said, "Indeed, we will destroy the people of that Lot's city. Indeed, its people have been wrongdoers."
[Abraham] said, "Indeed, within it is Lot." They said, "We are more knowing of who is within it. We will surely save him and his family, except his wife. She is to be of those who remain behind."

And when Our messengers came to Lot, he was distressed for them and felt for them great discomfort. They said, "Fear not, nor grieve. Indeed, we will save you and your family, except your wife; she is to be of those who remain behind.
Indeed, we will bring down on the people of this city punishment from the sky because they have been defiantly disobedient."
And We have certainly left of it a sign as clear evidence for a people who use reason.
And to Madyan [We sent] their brother Shu'ayb, and he said, "O my people, worship Allah and expect the Last Day and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption."
But they denied him, so the earthquake seized them, and they became within their home [corpses] fallen prone.

And [We destroyed] 'Aad and Thamud, and it has become clear to you from their [ruined] dwellings. And Satan had made pleasing to them their deeds and averted them from the path, and they were endowed with perception.
And [We destroyed] Qarun and Pharaoh and Haman. And Moses had already come to them with clear evidences, and they were arrogant in the land, but they were not outrunners [of Our punishment].

So each We seized for his sin; and among them were those upon whom We sent a storm of stones, and among them were those who were seized by the blast [from the sky], and among them were those whom We caused the earth to swallow, and among them were those whom We drowned. And Allah would not have wronged them, but it was they who were wronging themselves.
The example of those who take allies other than Allah is like that of the spider who takes a home. And indeed, the weakest of homes is the home of the spider, if they only knew.
Indeed, Allah knows whatever thing they call upon other than Him. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
And these examples We present to the people, but none will understand them except those of knowledge.

For the heart of the obedient righteous person, even if it is pure, the clarity of the Truth does not become apparent in it because he does not seek the Truth and does not align the mirror of his heart towards the direction of the sought object. Rather, perhaps he is preoccupied with detailing bodily acts of worship or preparing the means of livelihood, and does not direct his thought to contemplation in the presence of Lordship and the hidden divine realities. How could it not prevent true unveiling? The fourth is the Veil (Hijab). For the obedient one who subdues his desires, with thought detached in a reality among realities, that may not be unveiled to him because he is veiled from it by a belief that preceded him since childhood by way of blind following (Taqlid) and acceptance with good assumption. For that stands between him and the reality of the Truth and prevents from being unveiled in his heart anything contrary to what he received from the outward aspect of blind following. And this too is a great veil.

Let the speaker know his limit within the religion [din], and that his position within it is the position of a guard on the pilgrimage route. If the guard devotes himself solely to guarding, he is not among the pilgrims. And the speaker, if he devotes himself solely to disputation [munazara] and defense, and does not tread the path of the Hereafter [Akhira], and does not busy himself with tending to the heart [qalb] and its rectification, is not among the scholars of the religion [din] at all. What the speaker possesses of the religion [din] is only the creed [aqida] which he shares with all the common people, and it is among the outward works of the heart [qalb] and tongue. He is only distinguished from the commoner by the craft of argumentation [mujadala] and guarding. As for the knowledge [ma'rifa] of God, Exalted is He, and His attributes and His actions, and all that we have alluded to in the science of unveiling [ilm al-mukashafa], it is not attained through the science of theology [kalam]. Rather, theology [kalam] almost becomes a veil [hijab] over it and a barrier against it. The only way to reach it is through spiritual struggle [mujahada], which God, Glorified is He, made a prerequisite for guidance, as He, Exalted is He, said: "And those who strive in Us - We will surely guide them to Our ways. And indeed, Allah is with the doers of good." (Al-Ankabut: 69) If you say: "You have reduced the definition of the theologian [mutakallim] to guarding the creed [aqida] of the common people from the confusion of the innovators, just as the definition of the guard [badhriqa] is to guard the pilgrims' fabrics from being plundered by the Bedouins. And you have reduced the definition of the jurist [faqih] to preserving the law [qanun] by which the ruler restrains the harm of some aggressors from others. These are two lowly ranks in relation to the science of the religion [din]. And the scholars of the community [ummah] famous for virtue are the jurists [fuqaha] and the theologians [mutakallimun], and they are the best of creation with God, Exalted is He. So how do you lower their degrees to this lowly station in relation to the science of the religion [din]?" Then know that whoever knows the truth [haqq] by [knowing] men is lost in the wastelands of misguidance. Know the truth [haqq], then you will know its people, if you are a traveler on the path of truth [haqq]. And if you are content with imitation [taqlid] and looking at what is famous among people regarding degrees of virtue, then do not neglect the Companions [Sahaba] and the loftiness of their station. For those I have mentioned have unanimously agreed on their precedence, and that their level in the religion [din] cannot be reached, nor can their dust be approached. Their precedence was not due to theology [kalam] or jurisprudence [fiqh], but due to the knowledge [ilm] of the Hereafter [Akhira] and treading its path. "Abu Bakr, may God be pleased with him, did not surpass people by abundant fasting, nor prayer, nor by abundant narration [riwaya], nor legal verdicts [fatwa], nor speech [kalam], but by something that settled firmly in his chest." As the Master of the Messengers, peace and blessings be upon him, testified for him. So let your earnest desire be in seeking that secret [sirr], for it is the precious jewel and the hidden pearl. Leave aside what the majority of people agree upon and its glorification and magnification, for reasons and motives whose detailed explanation would be lengthy. For the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, was taken from thousands of Companions [Sahaba], may God be pleased with them, all of them knowers of God [arifun bi-llah], whom the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, praised. And among them, there was not a single one who was proficient in the craft of theology [kalam], nor did anyone appoint himself for issuing legal verdicts [fatwa] except about a dozen men.
